articles.headline: Bernanke Takes Sides on Debt Limit Vote
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke spoke out on the debt ceiling issue for the first time and sided with the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke spoke out on the debt ceiling issue for the first time and sided with the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, warned Congressional Republicans on Thursday not to “play around with” a coming vote to raise the government’s legal borrowing limit or use it as a bargaining chip for spending cuts.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Hid Doubts on Madoff, Documents Suggest
articles.snippet: Newly unsealed court documents show that bank executives were suspicious of Bernard Madoff’s accounts and steered clients away from him but did not alert regulators.
articles.abstract: Newly unsealed court documents show that bank executives were suspicious of Bernard Madoff’s accounts and steered clients away from him but did not alert regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senior executives at JPMorgan Chase expressed serious doubts about the legitimacy of Bernard L. Madoff’s investment business more than 18 months before his Ponzi scheme collapsed but continued to do business with him, according to internal bank documents made public in a lawsuit on Thursday.

articles.headline: From 1983, Hope for Jobs in 2011
articles.snippet: With the latest unemployment figures to be released Friday, there are signs that the economy is doing better than some statistics would indicate.
articles.abstract: With the latest unemployment figures to be released Friday, there are signs that the economy is doing better than some statistics would indicate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate declined four-tenths of a percentage point in one month. There had not been a monthly decline that large in many years, but economists were unimpressed. After all, the decline was caused in no small part by a surprising reduction in the labor force, which could be an indication that more workers were discouraged and no longer looking. That would hardly be an encouraging development.

articles.headline: Merkel, in Reversal, Urges Rescue of Euro
articles.snippet: Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, and the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, will present new ideas on Friday to save the euro and integrate euro zone economies.
articles.abstract: Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, and the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, will present new ideas on Friday to save the euro and integrate euro zone economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — For a year, as Europe struggled with its debt crisis, Germany’s chancellor, Angela Merkel, lived up to her nickname of “Frau Nein,” or Mrs. No, by stalling on each rescue effort.

articles.headline: In a Shift, Cubans Savor Working for Themselves
articles.snippet: Hoping to resuscitate Cuba’s crippled economy, President Raúl Castro has opened the door to a new, if limited, generation of entrepreneurs.
articles.abstract: Hoping to resuscitate Cuba’s crippled economy, President Raúl Castro has opened the door to a new, if limited, generation of entrepreneurs.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAUTA, Cuba  Marisela Álvarez spends much of the day bent over a single electric burner in her small outdoor kitchen. Her knees are killing her. Her red hair smells of cooking oil.

articles.headline: White House and Egypt Discuss Plan for Mubarak’s Exit
articles.snippet: President Hosni Mubarak has balked at leaving, but talks are continuing with Egyptian officials about a plan in which the vice president would begin reforms, officials said.
articles.abstract: President Hosni Mubarak has balked at leaving, but talks are continuing with Egyptian officials about a plan in which the vice president would begin reforms, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is discussing with Egyptian officials a proposal for President Hosni Mubarak to resign immediately and turn over power to a transitional government headed by Vice President Omar Suleiman with the support of the Egyptian military, administration officials and Arab diplomats said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Before Sunday, a Taste of the Bowl
articles.snippet: Trying to build buzz before the kickoff, many advertisers are offering previews of their commercials. Others are putting the full versions of their spots online.
articles.abstract: Trying to build buzz before the kickoff, many advertisers are offering previews of their commercials. Others are putting the full versions of their spots online.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, most Super Bowl advertisers followed a simple rule: Keep commercials under wraps until the moment they go on the air.

articles.headline: Egypt Officials Seek to Nudge Mubarak Out
articles.snippet: Egypt’s new vice president and other military leaders were discussing steps to limit President Hosni Mubarak’s decision-making authority, officials said.
articles.abstract: Egypt’s new vice president and other military leaders were discussing steps to limit President Hosni Mubarak’s decision-making authority, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  President Hosni Mubarak appeared increasingly isolated on Friday, as hundreds of thousands of protesters returned to Tahrir Square and the Obama administration and some members of the Egyptian military and civilian elite pursued plans to nudge him from power.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Jobs Report Offers a Mixed Bag, but Little Comfort
articles.snippet: The reported job growth of 36,000 jobs was well below forecasts, though some economists blamed the weather.
articles.abstract: The reported job growth of 36,000 jobs was well below forecasts, though some economists blamed the weather.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States labor market is still having trouble achieving liftoff.
